content.raw:
This pull request has been split and is no longer required.

* pull request #269 - misc changes to ign-transport itself
* pull request #270 - Inserting messages into a log file
* pull request #271 - Getting all messages from a log file
* pull request #272 - Querying for messages by topic name and type
* pull request #273 - Recording ignition-transport topics
* pull request #274 - Playing back ignition-transport topics
* pull request #275 - Integration tests for recording and playing back ignition-transport topics
* pull request #276 - `ign log` ign-tools command
content.html:
This pull request has been split and is no longer required.

  • pull request #269 - misc changes to ign-transport itself
  • pull request #270 - Inserting messages into a log file
  • pull request #271 - Getting all messages from a log file
  • pull request #272 - Querying for messages by topic name and type
  • pull request #273 - Recording ignition-transport topics
  • pull request #274 - Playing back ignition-transport topics
  • pull request #275 - Integration tests for recording and playing back ignition-transport topics
  • pull request #276 - ign log ign-tools command

update.description:
This pull request is intended to add record/playback capability using ignition-tools.

Done:

* Record topics using `ign log record`
* `Log` class handles inserting topics/messages into a log file
* `Record` class handles subscribing to ignition transport
* Simple unit tests for `Log` class
* Simple unit tests for `Record` class

TODO:

* More tests  so coverage passes
* Come up with ways of splitting up this PR

New dependencies

 * ignition-common0
 * SQLite3
 * ruby-ffi
update.title: [WIP] ignition tools record/playback

update.description:
WIP. This pull request is intended to add record/playback capability using ignition-tools.

Done:

* Record topics using `ign log record`
* `Log` class handles inserting topics/messages into a log file
* `Record` class handles subscribing to ignition transport
* Simple unit tests for `Log` class
* Simple unit tests for `Record` class

TODO:

* Add `Playback` class to compliment `Record`
* Playback command line implementation using `Playback` class
* Implement `Log` API to query messages (see [this confluence page](https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/99778575/Ignition+Log))
    * `Message` class
    * `TimeOptions` class
    * `TopicOptions` class
    * `MessageIterator` class (in wiki discussion)
* Tests for `Log` that use playback API to verify record AP
* Record needs to use raw-bytes subscriber (pull request #251)
* Integration tests for record and playback

Questions for @caguero :

* How can record get notified of new topics? For example, record may be launched before the thing it is supposed to record starts recording. Record would only be subscribed to the ones it saw at launch.

New dependencies

 * ignition-common0
 * SQLite3
 * ruby-ffi
update.title: [WIP] ignition tools record/playback

content.raw: Ahhhh, right, this is class definition scope, so the meaning of `static` is different. That must be the most irritatingly context-sensitive keyword in this entire language.
content.html: Ahhhh, right, this is class definition scope, so the meaning of static is different. That must be the most irritatingly context-sensitive keyword in this entire language.

Looks like I'm wrong here. Removing static leads to a compile time error when Recorder tries to use the constant it without an instance.

Also

#include <iostream>


class ConstCheck1
{
  public:
    const int member0 = 5;
    const int member1 = 5;
    const int member2 = 5;
    const int member3 = 5;
    const int member4 = 5;
    const int member5 = 5;
    const int member6 = 5;
    const int member7 = 5;
    const int member8 = 5;
    const int member9 = 5;
};


class StaticConstCheck1
{
  public:
    static const int member0 = 5;
    static const int member1 = 5;
    static const int member2 = 5;
    static const int member3 = 5;
    static const int member4 = 5;
    static const int member5 = 5;
    static const int member6 = 5;
    static const int member7 = 5;
    static const int member8 = 5;
    static const int member9 = 5;
};


int main(int argc, char ** argv)
{
  std::cout << "const only size: " << sizeof(ConstCheck1) << "\n";
  std::cout << "static const size: " << sizeof(StaticConstCheck1) << "\n";
  return 0;
}

non-static const does increase the size of the object, so the value is copied with each instance.

$ g++ --std=c++11 text.cpp 
$ ./a.out 
const only size: 40
static const size: 1

content.raw: Feel free to make any change
I guess we could name them `Beginning` and `Ending` if we have to, but then we should also change `SetStart` to `SetBeginning` and `SetFinish` to `SetEnding`.
content.html: I guess we could name them Beginning and Ending if we have to, but then we should also change SetStart to SetBeginning and SetFinish to SetEnding.

content.raw:
I really have to strongly object to removing the `Get` here. Having functions named `Start` and `Finish` (instead of `GetStart` and `GetFinish`) implies that something like a timer is being activated and deactivated.

We either have to violate the style guide here or come up with completely different function names.
content.html:
I really have to strongly object to removing the Get here. Having functions named Start and Finish (instead of GetStart and GetFinish) implies that something like a timer is being activated and deactivated.

We either have to violate the style guide here or come up with completely different function names.

content.raw:
For a moment there I thought `min` was referring to `minutes`.

That's definitely an interesting idea, and I'm certainly open to it. It has the benefit of leveraging built-in STL structures and a common language idiom instead of creating our own idiom that's specific to this API.

However, `min` and `max` explicitly indicate a direction, whereas the `indeterminate` concept can be used equally for both the beginning and end of a range. The "indeterminate" concept would become context-sensitive, and we would have to rework the `QualifiedTimeRange` concept to deal with the `min` vs `max` distinction.
content.html:
For a moment there I thought min was referring to minutes.

That's definitely an interesting idea, and I'm certainly open to it. It has the benefit of leveraging built-in STL structures and a common language idiom instead of creating our own idiom that's specific to this API.

However, min and max explicitly indicate a direction, whereas the indeterminate concept can be used equally for both the beginning and end of a range. The "indeterminate" concept would become context-sensitive, and we would have to rework the QualifiedTimeRange concept to deal with the min vs max distinction.

content.raw: An alternative would be to replace the indeterminate concept with `std::chrono::nanoseconds::min` for the beginning of all time and `std::chrono::nanoseconds::max` for the end of all time.
content.html: An alternative would be to replace the indeterminate concept with std::chrono::nanoseconds::min for the beginning of all time and std::chrono::nanoseconds::max for the end of all time.

It shouldn't necessarily be considered a blocker for this PR, but I consider this to be an insightful data point for a recurring issue.
content.html:
I'll add a link here to the comment I made on the commit.

It shouldn't necessarily be considered a blocker for this PR, but I consider this to be an insightful data point for a recurring issue.

* `Log` class handles inserting topics/messages into a log file
* `Record` class handles subscribing to ignition transport
* Simple unit tests for `Log` class
* Simple unit tests for `Record` class

TODO:

* Add `Playback` class to compliment `Record`
* Playback command line implementation using `Playback` class
* Implement `Log` API to query messages (see [this confluence page](https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/99778575/Ignition+Log))
    * `Message` class
    * `TimeOptions` class
    * `TopicOptions` class
    * `MessageIterator` class (in wiki discussion)
* Tests for `Log` that use playback API to verify record AP
* Record needs to use raw-bytes subscriber (pull request #251)
* Integration tests for record and playback

Questions for @caguero :

* How can record get notified of new topics? For example, record may be launched before the thing it is supposed to record starts recording. Record would only be subscribed to the ones it saw at launch.

New dependencies

 * ignition-common0
 * SQLite3
 * ruby-ffi
update.title: [WIP] ignition tools record/playback

content.raw: Note: need >=3.6.19 because that's the first version that added support for foreign key constraints.
content.html: Note: need >=3.6.19 because that's the first version that added support for foreign key constraints.

content.raw: I'm pretty sure `static` doesn't do anything here. If there are no objections I'll remove it. (same below)
content.html: I'm pretty sure static doesn't do anything here. If there are no objections I'll remove it. (same below)
